a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: The amount of memory available on a PC fixed media storage device, usually measured in Mega (million) bytes (Mb) of memory.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: Hypertext Markup Language. A set of tags used to mark the structural elements of text files. HTML files include tags that create hyperlinks to other documents on the Internet.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: Hypertext Transfer Protocol. The communications protocol on which the Web is based. HTTP sets rules for how information is passed between the server and the browser software.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: A picture or symbol that represents an object, task, command, or choice users can select by pointing and clicking with a mouse.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: A list of keywords the user may view to find topics within a Help system.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: The part of a computer that stores information or instructions. Memory can be RAM (Random Access Memory) or ROM (Read Only Memory), and is usually measured in Kilobytes (thousand) or Megabytes (million) bytes of memory.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: A collection of messages posted by individuals to a news server (a computer maintained by a company, group, or individual). Newsgroups exist on practically every subject. Messages can be posted and read by anyone who has access to that group.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: An individual topic within a Help system.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: A frame used to display program components.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: Screen shots and information about a product displayed in sequential order. Designed for a user who wants to walk through a feature or a program.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: Uniform Resource Locator. An Internet address, as well as a standard method of naming files on the Web. A URL begins with a protocol name (such as http), followed by a colon and two forward slashes(//). Next comes the name of the internet server that the file is stored on, followed by directories that hold the file, separated by forward slashes(/). The filename comes last, as shown in the following example: http://www.mycompany.com/whatsnew.htm

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: Commonly called a browser. A software application for displaying HTML pages on the World Wide Web. Common browser applications include Microsoft Internet Explorer and Netscape Navigator.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: World Wide Web. The graphical Internet hypertext service that uses the HTTP protocol to retrieve Web pages and other resources from Web servers.

a.onclick: FMCDropDown( this ); FMCScrollToVisible( window, this.parentNode.parentNode ); return false;

div.div: (What You See Is What You Get). A development option that allows you to view items in the editor as they will display for end-users.
